subject: AW: [junit] method dependency
msgSnippet: Just my two cent s: First I would try to refactor the compicated internal state structure within this class to some more stateless behaviour. If this is not
messageBody:
Just my two cent's:

First I would try to refactor the compicated internal state structure within
this class to some more stateless behaviour.

If this is not possible, I would add some tests like

testB_and_NotA(){

try {

obj.b();
} catch (SomeException e) {

assertions(e);
}
}

Sincerely Yours

Dr. Oliver Strebel

-----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----
Von: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Gesendet: Montag, 9. Juli 2001 16:17
An: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Betreff: RE: [junit] method dependency



Maybe this is what you are doing now... sorry if I've misunderstood. Is
there any reason we can think of that this is such a bad idea?


testA(){
obj.a();
assertions;
}
testB(){
obj.a();
obj.b();
assertions;
}
testC(){
obj.a();
obj.b();
obj.c();
assertions;
}

This is like setting up a test case within a test case.

-Jason

> In my class, I have methods A(),B(), C(), where A() must
> be called before B(), B() before C(). I have individual
> test cases for each method. In order to run the tests in
> the specified order, I must arrange the actual methods in
> the appropriate order. I know this is not a good thing,
> so how do I avoid it? I really hate to lump them into one
> testcase.
>
> Thanks,
>
>
> Scott
> :-> Change is inevitable except from vending machines.
>
